abstract:
250-word version:

Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of First Pass Effect in Mechanical Thrombectomy: ASTER Trial

Background: The first pass effect (FPE) refers to (near-)complete revascularization after a single device pass without rescue therapy, associated with improved outcomes in acute ischemic stroke. This study evaluates FPE rates and outcomes in the ASTER trial comparing stent retriever (SR) and contact aspiration (CA) techniques.

Methods: The ASTER trial was a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint trial conducted between October 2015 and October 2016. Adults with anterior circulation ischemic stroke within 6 hours of onset were randomized to SR (n=189) or CA (n=192). The primary outcome was favorable clinical outcome (mRS 0-2) at 90 days. Randomization was stratified by intravenous thrombolysis use, and angiographic outcomes were assessed by a blinded core laboratory.

Results: Of 336 patients analyzed, FPE was achieved in 97 (28.9%), with no significant difference between SR (31.3%) and CA (26.3%) (adjusted RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.54 to 1.31; p=0.44). FPE was associated with improved clinical outcomes (adjusted RR 1.38, 95% CI 1.22 to 1.56) and lower mortality (adjusted RR 0.56, 95% CI 0.35 to 0.88). FPE also resulted in fewer hemorrhagic transformations and procedural complications.

Interpretation: Both SR and CA achieved similar FPE rates, with FPE linked to better outcomes and reduced complications. Further research is needed to enhance FPE rates.

Trial registration: NCT02523261

Funding: Not specified.
